title: 113_hr4803
content: The Act may be cited as the "TSA Office of Inspection Accountability Act of 2014". Congress finds that TSA criminal investigators in the Office of Inspection do not meet the requirement of spending at least 50% of their time on criminal investigations, despite receiving premium pay. The TSA Office of Inspection primarily monitors criminal investigations by other agencies, investigates employee misconduct, and conducts inspections. The DHS IG estimates that misclassified criminal investigators could cost taxpayers $17 million over 5 years. This estimate may not include all related costs. The curr_chunk discusses aspects of law enforcement training, early retirement benefits, police vehicles, and weapons. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Administration, Assistant Secretary, and Inspector General. The Inspector General will review the data and methods used by the Assistant Secretary to identify eligible employees. If the data and methods are found to be inadequate or invalid, the Administration cannot hire new employees for the Office of Inspection until certain certifications are made to specified committees. The Inspector General will review the data and methods used by the Assistant Secretary to identify eligible employees. If found adequate, the Assistant Secretary can certify to the specified committees for hiring new employees for the Office of Inspection. SEC. 5. TSA Office of Inspection workforce certification. The Assistant Secretary must certify to Congress that only eligible employees are classified as criminal investigators and receive associated benefits. Non-eligible employees in criminal investigator positions will be reclassified. The Assistant Secretary must certify to Congress that only eligible employees are classified as criminal investigators and receive associated benefits. Non-eligible employees in criminal investigator positions will be reclassified if they do not spend at least 50% of their time on criminal investigative duties. The Assistant Secretary will estimate long-term cost savings resulting from this reclassification and report to relevant committees within 180 days of enactment, including savings from law enforcement training. The Assistant Secretary will estimate cost savings from law enforcement training, early retirement benefits, availability pay, and equipment for eligible criminal investigators. SEC. 6. Investigation of Federal Air Marshal Service use of federal firearms license. The Assistant Secretary must provide materials related to the Federal Air Marshal Service's use of a Federal firearms license to obtain discounted or free firearms for personal use, along with actions to prevent such misuse. This was passed by the House of Representatives on July 22, 2014. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 22, 2014, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
